title: Development Tools
content: NOTE: The tools in this module arePRE-REQUISITESfor the course. You would have used most of these before. If most of this is new to you, please take this course later.

title: Development Tools
content: Some tools are fundamental to data science because they are industry standards and widely used by data science professionals. Mastering these tools will align you with current best practices and making you more adaptable in a fast-evolving industry.

title: Development Tools
content: The tools we cover here are not just popular, they’re the core technology behind most of today’s data science and software development.

title: Deployment Tools
content: Any application you build is likely to be deployed somewhere. This section covers the most popular tools involved in deploying an application.

title: Large Language Models
content: This module covers the practical usage of large language models (LLMs).

title: Large Language Models
content:
LLMs incur a cost.For the May 2025 batch, useaipipe.orgas a proxy.

title: Data Sourcing
content:
Before you do any kind of data science, you obviously have to get the data to be able to analyze it, visualize it, narrate it, and deploy it.
And what we are going to cover in this module is how you get the data.

title: Data Sourcing
content: There are three ways you can get the data.

title: Data Sourcing
content: The first is you candownloadthe data. Either somebody gives you the data and says download it from here, or you are asked to download it from the internet because it’s a public data source. But that’s the first way—you download the data.

title: Data Sourcing
content: The second way is you canquery itfrom somewhere. It may be on a database. It may be available through an API. It may be available through a library. But these are ways in which you can selectively query parts of the data and stitch it together.

title: Data Sourcing
content: The third way is you have toscrape it. It’s not directly available in a convenient form that you can query or download. But it is, in fact, on a web page. It’s available on a PDF file. It’s available in a Word document. It’s available on an Excel file. It’s kind of structured, but you will have to figure out that structure and extract it from there.

title: Data Sourcing
content: In this module, we will be looking at the tools that will help you either download from a data source or query from an API or from a database or from a library. And finally, how you can scrape from different sources.

title: Data Preparation
content: Data preparation is crucial because raw data is rarely perfect.

title: Data Preparation
content: It often contains errors, inconsistencies, or missing values. For example, marks data may have ‘NA’ or ‘absent’ for non-attendees, which you need to handle.

title: Data Preparation
content: This section teaches you how to clean up data, convert it to different formats, aggregate it if required, and get a feel for the data before you analyze.

title: Data analysis
content: Data Analysis: Introduction PodcastbyNotebookLM

title: Data analysis
content: Once you’ve prepared the data, your next task is to analyze it to get insights that are not immediately obvious.

title: Data analysis
content: In this module, you’ll learn:

title: Data analysis
content: Statistical analysis: Calculate correlations, regressions, forecasts, and outliers usingspreadsheets

title: Data analysis
content: Data summarization: Aggregate and pivot data usingPythonanddatabases.

title: Data analysis
content: Geo-data Collection & Processing: Gather and process geospatial data using tools like Python (GeoPandas) and QGIS.

title: Data analysis
content: Geo-visualization: Create and visualize geospatial data on maps using Excel, QGIS, and Python libraries such as Folium.

title: Data analysis
content: Network & Proximity Analysis: Analyze geospatial relationships and perform network analysis to understand data distribution and clustering.

title: Data analysis
content: Storytelling & Decision Making: Develop narratives and make informed decisions based on geospatial data insights.
